rememberedPersonSummary.name: BRUCE  WALKER
story:
Thanks for supporting our fundraising. 

Amanda and Francesca have created this fundraising page to raise much needed funds for Macmillan Cancer Support.  

We have both lost people very close to us with cancer.  Amanda lost her husband Bruce in February 2020 and Frannie her friend and tennis partner Lisa Langton in February 2019.  We wanted to create something meaningful, positive - indeed fun - that would use creativity and humour to help generate much needed funds for Macmillan in the wake of this global pandemic.  

This is the purpose of Loopydesigns.online.  We don't expect to make a profit, but we would like to raise as much for Macmillan as we can along the way.  Indeed as soon as we have covered our costs, ALL our profit from this venture will be channelled straight to Macmillan via this page.  

Many cancer patients will have had their treatment delayed, cancelled or changed as a result of Covid-19.  And the lockdown and absence of fundraising events this year will result in a huge dent in revenue.

Please give generously if you can and help us reach our ambitious target for this excellent cause.

story:
This December, we're asking Marshalls to help us collectively travel the 2,500 miles from Landscape House to the North Pole!

We all enjoy indulging over the festive period, so why not take on this active challenge in December while also supporting our charity partner Macmillan?

Take on the challenge to run, cycle, swim or walk as many miles as possible from 1-17 December and why not encourage your friends and family to join you too! 

Track your miles on Strava (or something similar) and send a screenshot of your total miles to InternalCommunications@marshalls.co.uk by Thursday 17 December. 

We'll give the top 3 colleagues to cover the most miles will receive a prize!  You just need to make sure you donate a minimum of £3 on this page.

We're aiming to raise £2,500 which is enough to fund the opening of the Macmillan Support Line on Christmas Day morning.

story:
Hey everyone, first I want to say thank you for hitting up my page. I'm so glad I'm finally getting to partake in this charity gaming marathon. 

Unfortunately I have sad news; I very recently lost a close friend of mine to a long term battle with cancer. She was an absolute diamond, and deserved to live a long happy life. She will never be forgotten, rest in peace Amy!

 My main guy in my life, my gramps, is year on year battling with cancer - and has managed to survive for alot longer than expected. Its thanks to the amazing facilities, treatments and support from Macmillan that he's been able to be part of my life for as long as he has. The dude has been here long enough to become a great grandfather, and I am so grateful of this.

I want other people to have the opportunity that my grandfather has, to live life as long as possible, and to see life happen.

Let's raise money to support that, let's raise money to help others!

story:
My Step Challenge is a fun and simple way to raise money for the BHF. With every pound you raise and your support, we will be closer to beating heartbreak forever. My Step Challenge is a fun and simple way to raise money for the BHF. With every pound you raise and your support, we will be closer to beating heartbreak forever.

As some of you may know, my Dad had a heart attack a few years ago. Whilst it initially sounds traumatic.. he actually didn’t realise it was quite so serious at the time and mistakenly thought it was just a touch of indigestion. So, he thought the best course of action would be to sit down on the sofa and pour himself a large glass of whiskey! 😂🙈 When he started to experience shooting pains down his left arm he thankfully called an ambulance, was taken to the hospital, operated on immediately and was fine!
Sadly, last year Dad had another heart attack. This time he recognised the symptoms straight away and called an ambulance. However, somewhere along the way, the message that he was having a heart attack got lost in translation and wasn’t passed on to the right teams. He had to wait over an hour for an ambulance to arrive, by which point, he had called the nearest person to him and they had managed to bundle him into the car and went flying off down the country lanes of Wales. No sooner were they out of Dad’s road when the ambulance wails around the corner, whizzing past in the opposite direction! They managed to turn the car around, stop the ambulance and eventually rush Dad to the hospital. Upon arrival, he went straight into surgery and again- THANKFULLY, was operated on and after a difficult stay in intensive care, we are incredibly fortunate that he recovered.
The incredible medical technology that the British Heart Foundation funds the research and development of, saved my Dad’s life not once, but twice.
A kind, supportive, incredibly loving Dad, he guides my heart in so much of my life and what I do, I owe a debt of gratitude to every single person that has helped to keep him by my side. ❤️

Thanks for visiting my page! On March 27th, I’ll be chucking myself out of a plane headfirst at 10,000ft to raise money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. 

Earlier this year I lost my Grandad to vascular dementia, a progressive illness (one that gets worse over time) which saw him battle memory loss, confusion and have problems with speech and understanding.

I’ve chosen to fly for the British Heart Foundation because they help improve and save the lives of many people, including those with vascular dementia. Dementia as a whole is the UK’s biggest killer and there's no known cure. Every three minutes someone develops dementia, but with your help we know we can beat it! 

Please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

Tom

story:
Give the best gift this Christmas

Christmas is traditionally a time to spend with friends and
family and, all being well, this is something that we will be able to do
despite the challenging times.

However, for some people, every day brings fresh challenges
– every day with their child is a blessing. This Christmas, we want to make a real difference and so we are urging our tradespeople and customers to make a donation to the Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) Charity.

It is hard to imagine the pain of a parent seeing their child battling life-threating illnesses, or the loneliness and confusion of a child who just wants to be home for Christmas. Great Ormond Street Hospital is
a truly magical place – a place where, despite the fear and challenges that the children, families and staff face every day, they never forget how to smile, have fun and support each other.

The GOSH Charity supports the activities of the hospital in
four ways:

  1. Rebuilding and refurbishment to ensure that
    children, parents and employees have the best possible conditions  to help them face what lies ahead.
  2. Support for families and children – helping them
    to cope with their situation, share their journey with others and giving them a
    safe space to talk about how they are feeling.
  3. Research into health – new breakthroughs are
    happening all the time, and by contributing to research, GOSH can ensure that
    their patients have the best possible care.
  4. Life-saving medical equipment – the staff at
    GOSH are heroes, but they need a little help! The latest equipment helps them
    to ensure that every child has what they need, when they need it.

WE NEED YOU!

You can help us to change lives, to ease pain and suffering
and give parents and children precious days, months – years together. We don’t know about you, but we think that knocks the socks off, well, a pair of socks or a selection box!

WHAT CAN YOU DO?

Please make a donation to GOSH. Whether it’s £1 or £100, every penny you donate will transform lives and help bring a smile to a family’s face.

You can’t give your trade person a cuppa and a biscuit, so
why don’t you make a donation to GOSH on their behalf instead?

We are always so proud of our community of traders and customers, who always come together to help others, especially for those people who need it most this Christmas – we hope that you enjoy the warm fuzzy feeling you get from the knowledge that you have helped to change a life.

All the best, and Merry Christmas!

Gary

My dad Derek Batchelor (aka 'Batchy' or 'Delboy') suddenly passed away in his sleep on 10th November, 2020.  His funeral will be held on Friday 27th November, 2020 at 4.15pm here in Wales.  Dad was a lively character and enjoyed life to the fullest.  He particularly enjoyed his social side and the Clubs he was a member of and his local pub and I am sure his friends will raise a glass.  Having lost my nan (Dec 2016); grandad (Dec 2017) and mum (Dec 18) to lose my dad now in 2020 is tough.  More so because of the current UK pandemic his funeral will be subject to current rules which means many will not be able to come particularly the family from London where we originated.  He was not a flower - person more a beer person!!!lol   but because of this it was felt appropriate to have donations not only in lieu of flowers but also in his memory for this cause which was close to us all.   Please donate if you are able  or perhaps just raise a glass to him when you next can.    Thank you all xxxx

He was the best man I will ever know, and if I'm able to raise something that can go towards beating cancer and saving someone else's Grandad then it's worth it. 

I've done a couple half marathons over lockdown, but that's the furthest I've ran, well aware a marathon is double the distance and a bigger kettle of fish to tackle. 

I'm doing this marathon come rain or shine, on new years day, because let's face it, we can't exactly party this NYE. I thought it would be nice to start the year with my best foot forward (pun intended) and to end of a year of running (amateur-ishly) with the pinnacle of running, a marathon. Whether I run, walk or crawl I shall try my best to get the job done. 

Thank you again.

Stay Safe and Thank you.

We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
1st Radyr Guides have been learning about the impact we have as individuals on the world around us.  We are most concerned about the environment, pollution and the effect on everything that lives here.  We have also been exploring the changes we can make to have a positive impact.  For our fundraising activity, we have chosen to support the WWF and raise awareness of their work.

WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.name: WWF-UK
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
IF YOU GO DOWN TO THE WOODS TODAY

You might notice theres less wildlife than there used to be. Thats because half of all UK species are in decline  were losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate.

By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our countrys beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world.

Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

During this lockdown I was looking for something to focus on and motivate myself, having recently bought a rowing machine Concept2's holiday challenge fit the bill perfectly.

Concept2 themselves add a small donation to one of their partner charities every kilometre, once you have completed 100km with an extended target of 200km. I decided to create this page to increase the amount donated as much as possible given it is such a great cause. MSF do vital humanitarian work globally which has only been increased given the current pandemic, so anything you can give is greatly appreciated. 

For more information on the difference your donation would make please visit - https://msf.org.uk/

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
